title: Dead schoolboy’s mum slams parents of teenager who stabbed him for PR offensive
text:
Debbie Makki (L) has slammed the parents of a teenager who stabbed her son (Picture: MEN/PA)

A dead schoolboy’s mum has hit out at the wealthy parents of the boy who fatally stabbed her son.

Debbie Makki, 54, is unhappy Joshua Molnar’s mum and dad hired a PR agency after he was revealed as the person who knifed her son Yousef Makki, 17.

Molnar, 17, stabbed the Manchester Grammar School pupil in the heart during a fight in Hale Barns, in Cheshire, on March 2.

He was cleared of the murder and manslaughter of Yousef following a four-week trial at Manchester Crown Court in July, telling the jury he acted in self-defence after the scholarship pupil pulled a knife on him.

At the time his name was protected, with media banned from publishing any details which would lead to him being identified.

But an application by The Sunday Times to allow them to publish his name ahead of his 18th birthday on Tuesday was allowed by Mr Justice Bryan, the judge who presided over his trial.

Debbie Makki says she is still looking for justice for her dead son (Picture: MEN)

Yousef Makki was knifed to death in Hale Barns (Picture: PA)

Mrs Makki told The Daily Mail: ‘Who do the Molnars think they are having a publicist? They’re hardly Posh and Becks. They are shameless.

Advertisement

‘They have shown no remorse to us during or since the trial. We’ve never heard anything from them. Surely, as human beings they should sympathise with us losing such a huge part of our lives.

‘Instead, they seem to be more worried about tainting their reputations.’

Mrs Makki’s daughter Jade Akoum, 28, added: ‘They can have all the money in the world and use a PR company but they can’t change the fact their son killed Yousef and was troubled.”

The family confirmed they would be ‘exploring all avenues to ensure justice for Yousef’.

Yousef had won a scholarship to £13,000-a-year Manchester Grammar School, where he excelled academically.

The teenager acquitted of murdering Yousef Makki in a leafy Cheshire village can now be named as Joshua Molnar (Picture: PA)

Molnar was cleared of the murder and manslaughter (Picture: PA)

Molnar, Yousef (previously ‘Boy A’) and a third youth, ‘Boy B’ who still cannot be identified, had all been smoking cannabis together before the latter suggested getting £45 more from a dealer.

Prosecutors claimed the plan was to rob the dealer when he arrived, but Molnar and the second defendant were both cleared of attempted robbery.

Jurors heard Molnar was ‘jumped’ at the meeting point, prompting Yousef and the other boy to flee and leave Molnar to take a beating.

That attack was then the catalyst for the subsequent argument between the pals and the fatal stabbing of Yousef.

Molnar had become fixated with knives, living out ‘idiotic fantasies” of being a middle-class gangster, his trial heard.

The keen rugby player admitted perverting the course of justice by lying to police about what had happened and possession of a flick knife.

Molnar, who had been at one time a pupil at Ellesmere College, a £33,000-a-year boarding school in Shropshire, will be released from custody next March.

Molnar with mother Stephanie, who said he ‘will have to live with the responsibility of his role in this for the rest of his life’ (Picture: PA)

The second defendant was cleared of perverting the course of justice by allegedly lying to police – but also admitted possession of a flick knife. He was given a four-month detention order.

In a statement to The Sunday Times, Joshua’s mum Stephanie Molnar, who employed PR firm MC2 to handle press inquiries, said: ‘I cannot imagine what Yousef’s parents and family must be going through as they try to come to terms with this.

‘Joshua fully accepts responsibility for Yousef’s death in the act of self-defence and the impact of this acceptance is massive.

‘He will have to live with the responsibility of his role in this for the rest of his life.’

A pre-inquest hearing into the death of Yousef is scheduled for October 18 at Manchester Coroner’s Court.

description: A dead schoolboy’s mum has hit out at the wealthy parents of the boy who fatally stabbed her son.
